question_text: Calculate the working capacity of an MOF for CO2 capture given adsorption capacities of 8.6 mmol/g at feed conditions (40°C, 0.15 bar CO2) and 2.0 mmol/g at desorption conditions (200°C, 0.01 bar CO2). How does this compare to the energy required for regeneration if the heat of adsorption is 40 kJ/mol?
standard_answer: The working capacity is calculated as the difference between adsorption capacity at feed and desorption conditions: 8.6 mmol/g - 2.0 mmol/g = 6.6 mmol/g. This represents the net CO2 captured per cycle per gram of MOF. To assess energy requirements, the heat required for regeneration per gram of MOF is determined by the working capacity and the heat of adsorption. For 6.6 mmol/g of CO2 desorbed, the energy is (6.6 mmol/g) × (40 kJ/mol) = 264 J/g, since 1 mmol = 0.001 mol, so 6.6 mmol = 0.0066 mol, and 0.0066 mol × 40 kJ/mol = 0.264 kJ/g = 264 J/g. This energy must be supplied to break adsorbate-adsorbent bonds during desorption. Compared to other processes, such as amine-based capture which may require higher temperatures and have heats of adsorption around 60–80 kJ/mol, this MOF shows favorable energy characteristics due to its moderate heat of adsorption and high working capacity, but practical systems must also account for sensible heat to heat the MOF bed and heat losses.

original_text.2: Mg-MOF-74 possesses the highest working capacity for post-combustion CO2 sequestration at 5.87 mmol g−1 at ambient temperature.
